items.synopsis: A deep divide has arisen over the High Court and role it could play over a Voice to Parliament. For some, it's raising echoes of past Indigenous rights battles, writes Elizabeth Byrne.

title.children: The Voice offers echoes from debate around past High Court decisions

image.altText: Netta, former Eurovision winner from Israel, performs during dress rehearsals for the Grand final at the Eurovision Song Contest

items.synopsis: After two rounds of semis, 26 countries are facing off in Liverpool, UK, to be crowned the winner of Eurovision 2023.

title.children: Winner announced in the Eurovision 2023 grand final

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some say numbers mean nothing at Eurovision, and others say they mean a lot - some even point to a curse at the Contest. Whether you are superstitious or not, it is a fact that of the 66 previous editions of Eurovision before tonight, the only place in the running order that has not brought a winner is number two. Four of the last seven winners have come from between 10th and 12th in the running order. Overall, since the introduction of televoting in 1998, the most common winners' places in the order have been 10th, 11th, 17th, 19th, 22nd and 24th (two each). This year, Portugal is in the death spot in second, while Albania is in 10th, Italy is in 11th, Armenia is in 17th, Ukraine is in 19th, Lithuania is in 22nd and Slovenia is in 24th.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The Numbers Game - The Curse of Number Two

children.content: Some say numbers mean nothing at Eurovision, and others say they mean a lot - some even point to a curse at the Contest.
Whether you are superstitious or not, it is a fact that of the 66 previous editions of Eurovision before tonight, the only place in the running order that has not brought a winner is number two.
Four of the last seven winners have come from between 10th and 12th in the running order.
Overall, since the introduction of televoting in 1998, the most common winners' places in the order have been 10th, 11th, 17th, 19th, 22nd and 24th (two each).
is in the death spot in second, while

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Just cause we're not in Europe doesn't mean we can't vote in Eurovision! But it does mean we can only vote online. So if you see an act you like, take note of their number and head to www.esc.vote to vote. There's a limit of 20 votes per person and, fair warning, each vote does cost 65c. And, as always you can not vote for your own country. So, Aussies can't vote for Voyager unfortunately - but you might have a couple overseas friends and family that can.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Voting is open and Aussies can get in on it

children.content: Europe doesn't mean we can't vote in Eurovision!

you can not vote for your own country

but you might have a couple overseas friends and family that can.

image.altText: Bernard Arnault stands between his two oldest children

items.synopsis: When the world's richest person sits down for monthly lunches in Paris with his five children, he's searching for his successor. Welcome to the house of Arnault.

title.children: He's called the 'wolf in cashmere'. Now the world's richest man needs to pick a child to succeed him

image.altText: A collage of three photos of people with their faces scratched out.

items.synopsis: While state care is a necessary last resort for many, horror stories have painted a bleak picture of the system that operates behind a veil of secrecy. But as Cason Ho writes, change may be afoot.

title.children: Faceless agents control the lives of thousands. Slowly, that wall of secrecy is crumbling

image.altText: Woman with hat standing in her crop in the bright warm morning sun

items.synopsis: If El Niño develops as expected, Australia is likely to see a reduction in rain, warmer average maximum temperatures, increased frequency and intensity of extreme hot days and a heightened risk of bushfires.

title.children: US climate agency says likelihood of El Niño this year now above 90 per cent

image.altText: Jim Chalmers holds the budget while standing outside Parliament House

items.synopsis: How does this week's federal budget fare as a moral document? Simply: the rich do better than the poor, writes Stan Grant.

title.children: When the rich get richer and the poor get left behind, we must ask: How does this budget fare as a moral document?

image.altText: Emergency service and other vehicles at a beach.

items.synopsis: Emergency services searching for a man believed to have been killed in a shark attack off South Australia's Eyre Peninsula say they have recovered the man's surfboard, and that there were several witnesses to the incident.

title.children: Surfer's board recovered after suspected fatal shark attack off SA's Eyre Peninsula

image.altText: A close up picture of a green motherboard.

items.synopsis: If digital technology were a country, it'd be the third-biggest energy consumer behind China and the US. Every text, email, and online search emits carbon – so, what can we do about it?

title.children: Have you thought about your digital carbon footprint? Here's how to reduce it

image.altText: A sign indicating digital yuan, also referred to as e-CNY

items.synopsis: Starting this month, thousands of workers in a Chinese city will be paid their wages entirely in digital yuan, in what has been described by the central government as a "milestone" for the currency.

title.children: Fears over 'absolute control' as Chinese city pays thousands of workers in digital yuan

image.altText: A selfie of Ayman and Samiha, both smiling warmly, a park pathway visible behind them.

items.synopsis: A doctor couple helps to buy and fix up an old church in Wagga Wagga, NSW, fixing the town's chronic shortage of GPs.

title.children: Amid a chronic GP shortage, Wagga Wagga manages to recruit 47 overseas-trained doctors

image.altText: a non-identifying photo of a boy on a beachside swing

items.synopsis: Confronting evidence reveals how two brothers with autism were let down for years by the government agencies supposed to protect them, Rachel Riga writes.

title.children: Two malnourished brothers were found locked in a room. The case reveals shameful government failures

image.altText: Pope Francis (L) shakes hands with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

items.synopsis: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy asks Pope Francis for backing on Kyiv's peace plan and the repatriation of Ukrainian children taken by Russians.

title.children: Ukrainian president meets pope during Rome visit

image.altText: A close-up selfie of an older Samoan woman and a young Samoan man. Both have slight smiles on their faces.

items.synopsis: Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs back Fa'amanu Brown has gone to dark places during his footy career, but caring for his dying mother brought him back to his true self.

title.children: Through depression, suicidal ideation and injuries, Fa'amanu Brown found salvation caring for his dying mother

image.altText: Teenage boy sitting on curb outside of train station at night.

items.synopsis: After abuse tore Tony's childhood apart, he joined a crime gang and became a drug dealer. It almost took his life, but a random street encounter changed everything.

title.children: Meet Tony, the drug-dealing gangster turned clean-living pastor

image.altText: An Indian man looks down as he walks outside a parliament building in New Delhi.

items.synopsis: India's top wrestlers, including two Olympic medallists, make allegations of sexual harassment and exploitation, threatening huge implications for a country where women's sport is only now gaining time in the spotlight.

title.children: Wrestling for justice — Indian athletes strike against high-profile MP accused of abuse

image.altText: Owen Davidson pictured during a Wimbledon match in 1971.

items.synopsis: Owen Davidson — who won 13 major doubles titles and was inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame — is warmly remembered by friends and fellow players following his death in Texas.

title.children: 'A great mate': Tributes flow as Aussie tennis legend dies, aged 79

image.altText: A middle-age man with a moutasche has a serious expression.

items.synopsis: El Chapo's sons were once mocked as entitled princelings, yet the brothers have resuscitated a drug empire and diversified the business by embracing a new line of synthetic drugs.

title.children: How El Chapo's four sons — Los Chapitos — built a fentanyl empire that is now poisoning America

image.altText: Tia Bridge holds baby Chelsea in the air and both smiling at each other

items.synopsis: Tia Bridge plans a low-key Mother's Day with her family, reflecting on being a mother to three children — Lachlan, Chelsea and a little girl she has nicknamed "Immy", who never drew a breath.

title.children: 'Every time I see a butterfly, I think of her': This Mother's Day will be bittersweet for Tia

image.altText: Mother and daughter hugging each other, gorge and mountains behind.

items.synopsis: Melissa Mills believes there's no stronger bond than that between a mother and child – and she wants to capture it visually, forever. She is photographing women and their children at "matriarchal" sites in Queensland's Carnarvon Gorge.

title.children: Photographer captures 'invisible' bond between mums and kids

image.altText: Photo of a sheep with an ear tag.

items.synopsis: Farmers say it's like having a shepherd guarding stock the whole time. Eartag satellite-tracking technology could save them millions of dollars and a lot of heartache.

title.children: This pocket-sized gadget could be the answer to stopping livestock theft

image.altText: A crowd of people holds signs at a rally

items.synopsis: Senator Jacqui Lambie sends a blunt message to the Tasmanian government and the state Greens leader tells thousands opposed to the AFL stadium proposed for Hobart's waterfront she will work to defund it.

title.children: Thousands turn out to oppose AFL stadium deal as Lambie tells premier to 'stick it'

image.altText: A sheep with a wooly jumper on at Homebush farm, north-west of Stanthorpe.

items.synopsis: With winter approaching, the sheep grazier warning becomes a frequent and chilling feature of ABC weather forecasts and alerts from the Bureau of Meteorology. What does it mean for farmers? And sheep?

title.children: The sheep don't know it, but the Bureau of Meteorology regularly saves them from a chilly and unpleasant death

image.altText: Children look through the smashed window of small white hatchback.

items.synopsis: Islamic Jihad says it is prepared for "months of confrontation" while Israel says the onus is on Palestinian militants to stop launching rockets from an arsenal it suggests could be depleted within days.

title.children: Israel rules out truce with Islamic Jihad as two West Bank Palestinians killed on fifth day of fighting

image.altText: An elderly-looking lion sits among grass and mud.

items.synopsis: A Kenyan lion believed to have been the world's oldest in the wild has died after being speared by herders when he reportedly strayed into a livestock pen.

title.children: 'Legendary' lion Loonkito, one of the world's oldest, speared by herders in Kenya

image.altText: Pakistani police in riot gear stand outside the high court.

items.synopsis: Pakistan's Prime Minister Shahbaz Sharif orders authorities to identify and arrest all those involved in violent acts after former prime minister Imran Khan's arrest this week sparked deadly unrest.

title.children: Pakistan's PM orders police to arrest those involved in Imran Khan protests

image.altText: A stone temple buried underneath rocks

items.synopsis: Experts believe people carried out religious ceremonies in the U-shaped temple after discovery a carving of an ancient cross symbol.

title.children: Archaeologists discover 4,000-year-old temple in western Peru

image.altText: A wooden thermometer climbs to 40 degrees Celsius.

items.synopsis: Once trusted faces on the news, meteorologists now brave threats, insults and slander online from conspiracy theorists and climate change deniers who accuse them of faking or even fixing the weather.

title.children: Chemtrails, doctored temperatures and exaggerated global warming: Meteorology is new misinformation target

image.altText: A naked man stands with his arm around a naked woman on a beach.

items.synopsis: Queensland is the only mainland state where nudist beaches are illegal, but a recent police blitz has sparked a discussion about legislative change.

title.children: Noosa nudists seek amnesty after police crackdown

image.altText: A GPS tracker on the ankle of somebody wearing jeans

items.synopsis: Bob Atkinson, who also sat on the Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse, says the use of GPS trackers may be a useful tool into the future, despite a low uptake during a Queensland trial.

title.children: Can GPS trackers help curb youth crime? Former top cop says the 'door should be left open' as trial continues

image.altText: A woman wields an axe from a car door.

items.synopsis: Police have now charged a road crash victim who wielded an axe and allegedly threatened emergency service workers when they tried to rescue her when her car rolled in Adelaide's south on Friday night.

title.children: Crash victim brandishes axe as emergency staff try to rescue her from rolled car

image.altText: The plant has spiked leaves and small green blueberry-shaped fruit.

items.synopsis: The blueberry family officially has a new member, thanks to two council workers who noticed a strange-looking plant growing in a roadside reserve in rural Western Australia.

title.children: How a walk along a WA country road led council workers to a plant species unknown to science

image.altText: Prince William and Prince George stand either side of King Charles III as he sits on his throne at Buckingham Palace

items.synopsis: The royal family releases an official portrait of King Charles III alongside his direct heirs, Prince William and Prince George, as part of new photos released taken on the day of the King's coronation.

title.children: Three generations of royals pose together in new official portrait
